contents.description: Send email to  or chat (Matrix/Element or Slack, both rooms are linked) with a member of the Species File Group.

contents.description: Bring your perspectives on how to "Describe Life" to the 4th annual event on TaxonWorks, its community, and the broader world of biodiversity informatics
contents.title: Event
How
contents.subtitle: All sessions virtual (Zoom) and free to attend. Registration is required. Space may be limited.

steps.title: Register
steps.text: Take the first step and [register](https://illinois.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZclc-6spj4oH9Ztn5mcUjor0r89nufWZjp1) for free with your email which sends you your Zoom link.

steps.title: Participate
steps.text: [Post ideas, requests, questions](https://github.com/SpeciesFileGroup/taxonworks_together_2023/issues) for our event sessions.

steps.title: 3 Minutes 1 Slide
steps.text: If you would like to present your insights or ideas on a given topic about TaxonWorks let us know we'll add you to the list

steps.title: Notes
steps.text: Notes doc (accessible soon) for TaxonWorks Together 2023

more.title: Learn about TaxonWorks
more.text: New to TaxonWorks? Learn about TaxonWorks features and functions via the TaxonWorks YouTube videos and visit the [online documentation](https://docs.taxonworks.org/).

more.title: Get a TaxonWorks account
more.text: Discover TaxonWorks in a sandbox now. It's ready-to-use, no software installation needed, [Contact us](#contact).

more.title: Get a GitHub account
more.text: Not required, but recommended. [A GitHub account](https://github.com/) will help you better participate in many aspects of the community and help you get recognition for the work and expertise you contribute.

more.title: Install it
more.text: If you are software developer and you want to hack TaxonWorks itself, please start reading install_taxonworks. You Don't Need To Install TW locally to use it. (See number 2 above).

more.title: Experiment
more.text: Got data in TaxonWorks already? Looking to experiment to see what your TaxonPages will look like? Try installing this software "locally" (on your computer) to find out. (You will need to install Node on your machine, and git, there’s a link in the above instructions). You can also "see" other sites, if their API is open, look here: https://sandcastle.taxonworks.org/api/v1.

contents.subtitle: Scheduled events and times are subject to changes until this message goes away! All events will have question / answer / discussion time.

schedule.topic: In practice - Current use of TaxonWorks with an eye to the future

schedule.title: Welcome and overview
schedule.description: The weeks topics, an invitation to present and participate. Forums for participation. Meeting norms.

schedule.title: Audience poll and time for questions
schedule.description: Share a little about what brings you and your fellow participants to TaxonWorks together. Emphasize what you want to take away from TWT.

schedule.title: Symposium - Voices from TaxonWorks Projects - I
schedule.description: Insects and their names! Hyper-diverse taxa. New portals. BBQs.

speakers.name: Heidi Hopkins
speakers.title: On the Small orders and recent work

speakers.name: James Woolley, John Heraty, et al
speakers.title: The Universal Chalcidoidea Database Group

schedule.title: Symposium - The Future of Species Description
schedule.description: Producing taxonomic descriptions: technology, inventories, integration, AI use. Extended specimen tools for Collections and Taxonomists. How far does the specimen extend?

speakers.name: Matt Yoder
speakers.title: Setting the stage for the conversation

schedule.title: Discussion
schedule.description: Your ideas on the future.

schedule.title: 3 minutes, 1 slide - I
schedule.description: Your topic, your theme, your work.

schedule.title: Unconference I
schedule.description: Topics selected, proposed and prioritized by you, with a little guidance from the organizers. Parallel sessions possible. A chance for in-depth conversations here.

schedule.topic: IRL (In Real Life) - The Latest from TaxonWorks the and Species File Group

schedule.title: Welcome
schedule.description: Past day's review. this day, an invitation to present and participate. Forums for participation. Meeting norms.

schedule.title: The latest from TaxonWorks
schedule.description: Quick highlights and demonstrations and Q/A on the new unified filters, biological associations, catalogs, maps, and more

schedule.title: Symposium - Perspectives on taxon pages
schedule.description: !!- If you have a perspective you want to share, contact us -!!  It used to be that everyone wanted their own website with taxon pages, do they still? Just what is a taxon page? Who do they reach and serve? How should they evolve? What impact will AI have on them? How long should the last? What should they look like? What do past efforts tell us? What are the needs of young researchers?

speakers.name: Jennifer Hammock, Smithsonian
speakers.title: The View from Encyclopedia of Life

speakers.name: José Luis Pereira
speakers.title: Introducing TaxonPages: An Open-Source Companion for TaxonWorks and Related Software

speakers.name: Elycia Wallis, CSIRO
speakers.title: In a special session - The View from the Atlas of Living Australia

schedule.title: Symposium - Close companions: More from the Species File Group
schedule.description: Do more with your biodiversity data with tools and tricks from the Species File Group and their collaborators. Get insights on how the SFG facilitates biodiversity informatics research with their collaborators.

speakers.name: Dmitry Mozzerhin
speakers.title: Global Names: Highlighting New Integrations and Existing Functionality.

speakers.name: Geoff Ower & Yuri Roskov
speakers.title: Actionable Data Validation, from TaxonWorks to ChecklistBank

speakers.name: Deborah Paul
speakers.title: The Biodiversity Informatics of People in TaxonWorks and Beyond

speakers.name: Dmitry Dmitriev
speakers.title: SFG's Process of Accessioning Legacy Biodiversity Data into TaxonWorks

speakers.name: Geoff Ower
speakers.title: Wrapping APIs in Ruby, a flurry of new gems from the SFG

schedule.title: 3 minutes, 1 slide - II
schedule.description: Your topic, your theme, your work.

schedule.title: Unconference II
schedule.description: Topics selected, proposed and prioritized by you, with a little guidance from the organizers. Parallel sessions possible. A chance for in-depth conversations here.
topics: New TaxonPages in 30 minutes or less

schedule.title: Late Nite TaxonWorks: Taxon Pages Perspectives from the Atlas of Living Australia
schedule.description: An unconference-style conversation about Taxon Pages - continuing the discussion we started in an earlier session. We start this session off with a talk from the current chair of Biodiversity Information Standards (TDWG), Ely Wallis. She brings us the latest on thinking about the evolution of Taxon Pages from the Atlas of Living Australia. Time for your insights here.

schedule.title: Welcome
schedule.description: Past day's review. This day. An invitation to present and participate. Forums for participation. Meeting norms.

schedule.title: Symposium - The evolving landscape of biodiversity informatics: bringing actionable practices and tools to practitioners
schedule.description: Targeted topics (TBD): Community-based Geospatial Efforts. RCC-5. Evolving semantics and data modelling. Chronostratigraphy. Ontology integration. API integration. The Extended Specimen.

speakers.name: Nicky Nicolson, Eve Lucas
speakers.title: Creating communities and research workflow with an extensible notebook for open science on specimens

schedule.title: Symposium - Voices from TaxonWorks Projects - II
schedule.description: More insects, many more names. Sharing data (and teaching, learning) among a community of users (sources, people, names).

speakers.name: Maria Marta Cigliano
speakers.title: Perspectives from the Orthoptera Species File

schedule.title: SFG Business Meeting
schedule.description: The SFG collaborates with a lot of people. A review of expectations and norms, a report on sustainabilty and where we're at. Your chance as a collaborator (or would-be collaborator) to ask the tough questions of the SFG and its resources.

schedule.title: 3 minutes, 1 slide - III
schedule.description: Your topic, your theme, your work.

schedule.title: Making and sharing desktop-based videos
schedule.description: A collective exercise in figure out how to record, edit, and share short videos.  We don't know how, do you? Think TikTok for TaxonWorks, or your lab's bugs, or your favourite software. Bring your knowledge and lets see what we can get done in a short time.

schedule.title: Unconference III
schedule.description: Topics selected, proposed and prioritized by you, with a little guidance from the organizers. Parallel sessions possible. A chance for in-depth conversations here.

contents.title: RudolfMeier
What
contents.description: Our 4th TaxonWorks Together event (24 - 26 October 2023). Join us for 3 days of activities centered around building the TaxonWorks community, highlighting what's new, what's changed, and what is on the horizon.  Some activities will be highly guided, some information style, and some unconference style. These activities are open events and Your feedback and contributions will make a difference. Learn from those using TaxonWorks in their taxonomic and digitization workflows. See demos of powerful new ways to query and update data and new interfaces for managing biological associations, i.e. ways to explore and extend digital specimens. See examples of community-building around complex goals of curating data on some of the World's most hyper-diverse taxa.  Hear about TaxonWorks' companions, software, people, and data that extend the core functionality and use of the software. For example TaxonPages is a new open-source code base that produces, well, taxon pages, see how its producing well over 100k pages for the Species File Group. Get the broader perspective at special sessions that move beyond TaxonWorks to look at the role of taxon pages and how the practices behind taxonomic descriptions and biodiversity informatics might evolve.Hear about where TaxonWorks can be improved, and what the challenges behind those improvements are.

Your feedback and contributions will make a difference.

Learn from those using TaxonWorks in their taxonomic and digitization workflows. See demos of powerful new ways to query and update data and new interfaces for managing biological associations, i.e. ways to explore and extend digital specimens. See examples of community-building around complex goals of curating data on some of the World's most hyper-diverse taxa.  Hear about TaxonWorks' companions, software, people, and data that extend the core functionality and use of the software. For example TaxonPages is a new open-source code base that produces, well, taxon pages, see how its producing well over 100k pages for the Species File Group. Get the broader perspective at special sessions that move beyond TaxonWorks to look at the role of taxon pages and how the practices behind taxonomic descriptions and biodiversity informatics might evolve.Hear about where TaxonWorks can be improved, and what the challenges behind those improvements are.
As always, we invite new audiences to join us to gather insights for tailoring future directions.
Expect lots of opportunities to ask questions, meet others, and to contribute the conversation.
Can't wait to participate? If you want to share a longer perspective at TWT 2023 on the role of taxon pages or how the process of taxonomic circumscription might evolve propose it to us! See
Now! Plan your 3-minutes 1 slide presentation. Each day an open session where you can emphasize what's important to your biodiversity informatics world, whether TaxonWorks related or not.

contents.title: Who
contents.description: Taxonomists, students, ecologists, curators, collection managers, software developers, biodiversity information scientists, para-taxonomists. If you have questions about TaxonWorks this is a great time to ask them. If you have a vision to share, this is the place. Whether you are very familiar with TaxonWorks or new to our community, all are welcome.
